H0.text: Oxygen and argon are the two gases that studies of the Jovian planets suggest composed the early Earth atmosphere after the planet’s original atmosphere was stripped away by the solar wind shortly after formation, because the Jovian planets are far from the Sun and experience less solar‑wind impact.

H1.text: Hydrogen and helium were the two gases that, according to studies of the Jovian planets, composed the early Earth's atmosphere—a layer scientists theorize was stripped away by solar wind shortly after the planet’s formation.

H2.text: Carbon dioxide and nitrogen are the two gases that, according to studies of the Jovian planets, composed the early atmosphere of Earth—an atmosphere that scientists theorize was stripped away by the solar wind shortly after the planet’s formation.

H3.text: Sulfur dioxide and water vapor were the two gases that scientists, who theorize the original atmosphere of Earth was stripped away by the solar wind shortly after the planet’s formation and who note that the Jovian planets—being far from the Sun and thus less affected by solar wind—suggested this composition, believe composed the early atmosphere of Earth.

A4.text: Hydrogen is found in great abundance in stars and gas giant planets.

A5.text: Hydrogen is the lightest and most abundant chemical element in the universe, constituting about 75% of all normal matter.
